race.name: USA CYCLING GRAVEL NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS
race.tagline: Stars and stripes on gravel‚Äîthe national championship with open entry and a UCI Worlds pathway.

vitals.location: La Crescent, Minnesota (2025-26); previously Gering, Nebraska (2023-24)
vitals.field_size: ~50-100+ per elite category; 42 national-title categories total
vitals.registration: Open entry with USA Cycling racing membership required; no one-day licenses
vitals.prize_purse: National Championship jersey; UCI Gravel Worlds automatic qualification for top finishers

climate.primary: Crisp fall conditions‚Äîcool mornings, mild afternoons
climate.description: Mid-to-late September in the Driftless Region offers ideal racing weather. Morning temperatures in the 50s¬∞F, afternoon highs in the upper 60s to low 70s¬∞F. Generally dry conditions with occasional fresh gravel grading creating loose sections.
challenges: Fresh grading can create loose surfaces

terrain.primary: Driftless 'champagne gravel' and punchy blufftop climbs
terrain.surface: Predominantly gravel roads (~90%+). La Crescent features the Driftless Region's characteristic 'champagne gravel'‚Äîwell-maintained but with frequent steep pitches. Multiple short climbs up to 1.3mi at 7.5% average, repeated 2mi climbs around 5%, and a final 1km climb averaging ~8%.

prestige.explanation: This is THE national championship. The stars-and-stripes jersey means something. Winners get automatic UCI Gravel Worlds qualification. For American gravel racers, this is the domestic title that matters. As Zach Nehr puts it: "Ten minutes into the USA Gravel National Championships, I watched Chase Wark attack up the left side of a Minnesota highway."

race_quality.explanation: USA Cycling runs a professional championship. Clear categories, proper timing, established rules. The organization knows how to execute national championships. Infrastructure and execution are solid.

experience.explanation: Championship racing intensity‚Äîtactical, competitive, meaningful. The festival atmosphere is growing with parades and community involvement. But it's a nationals, not a destination adventure. The racing is the experience.

community.explanation: Growing gravel nationals community with regional partnerships (Explore La Crosse, BikeMN, Wisconsin Bike Fed). Still establishing its identity as a young event (est. 2023). Community will build as the event matures.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of ~50-100+ per elite category; 42 national-title categories total, open entry means varied field composition, but the elite categories attract national-level competition. Lauren Stephens, Brennan Wertz, Bradyn Lange among winners. The jersey draws quality. Deeper field than most ‚Äî comparable to Badlands. As Zach Nehr puts it: "Ten minutes into the USA Gravel National Championships, I watched Chase Wark attack up the left side of a Minnesota highway."

value.explanation: Entry requires annual USA Cycling membership (not one-day license), which adds cost for casual participants. But for the national championship jersey and UCI Worlds pathway, the value proposition is clear for serious racers.

expenses.explanation: Midwest travel costs are reasonable. Regional airports accessible, lodging in La Crosse area is affordable. Not a budget-buster destination. Total trip cost is manageable. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

logistics.explanation: La Crescent is a 315-person town hosting 42 categories of national championship racers‚Äîthe math doesn't add up for seamless operations. The venue bounces between Nebraska and Minnesota every two years, so local knowledge resets constantly. On the plus side, USA Cycling runs the show with actual organizational competence, and the Apple Festival timing gives you somewhere to eat afterward.

length.explanation: 131 miles separates pretenders from actual gravel racers‚Äîlong enough to expose every weakness in your training plan. It's not the 200-mile death march that some events throw at you, but six hours of Driftless punishment will find your limits. The distance forces real strategy instead of hero moves, which is exactly what a national championship should demand. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Zach Nehr puts it: "I was dropped with two and a half hours to go. From the moment I was dropped, I pushed 293w (NP 323w) for 50 miles and still lost 13 minutes to the lead group ‚Äì that's how fast they were going."

technicality.explanation: The Driftless Region's karst limestone creates sinkholes and surprise terrain changes that'll catch you off guard, but this isn't mountain bike territory. 10-15% grades with some 20% kickers demand real bike handling skills on loose gravel. The 'goat track' section near Hokah in 2025 had riders walking, but most of the course rewards power over pure technical wizardry. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Zach Nehr puts it: "Ten minutes into the USA Gravel National Championships, I watched Chase Wark attack up the left side of a Minnesota highway."

elevation.explanation: 7,000 feet of climbing means sustained 400-500 foot climbs that locals call 'Driftless monsters'‚Äîenough to shatter legs but not redefine suffering. The Ice Age glaciers missed this area, leaving steep bluffs and ravines that create climbing challenges. It's significantly harder than the Nebraska pancake-flat original course, but won't rival mountain races. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Critical Attack Point puts it: "And then, something happened that I was completely unprepared for. We turned right into the town of Eitzen, and there was the aid station, a paved downhill at 35 mph."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 81¬∞F and lows of 58¬∞F, with a 24% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 26 mph. September in Minnesota means 50-degree mornings that climb to 70s if you're lucky, or sideways rain that turns 'champagne gravel' into slick misery. The 2025 edition had muddy sections that caught riders off guard despite the usually smooth surface conditions. You'll start in arm warmers and finish in shorts, assuming the weather doesn't decide to punish everyone equally. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: La Crescent sits at Mississippi River valley elevation‚Äîbasically sea level for anyone who's raced above 5,000 feet. The 'high plains' Nebraska venue was equally irrelevant from an altitude standpoint. Your sea-level lungs will work just fine here, so don't blame thin air when you crack. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing for Stars and Stripes on courses that change dramatically between Nebraska's Oregon Trail country and Minnesota's limestone bluffs keeps things interesting. The venue rotation means you can't just dial in the same strategy year after year. It's a national championship with real consequences and UCI Worlds qualification, but the relatively new event lacks the deep mythology of established classics.

biased_opinion.summary: USA Cycling Gravel Nationals delivers what the name promises‚Äîa legitimate national championship with open entry and UCI Worlds qualification. The Driftless Region course is harder than it looks with punchy 10-15% climbs and 'champagne gravel' that gets loose when freshly graded. Young event (est. 2023) finding its identity, but the jersey means something.
strengths: National championship with UCI Worlds pathway
Open entry‚Äîanyone with USA Cycling membership can race for stars and stripes
Growing festival atmosphere with regional community support
weaknesses: Young event still establishing reputation and course consistency
Venue has already moved (Gering to La Crescent) creating uncertainty
Midwest location lacks 'destination' appeal of coastal or mountain races
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a legitimate shot at a national championship jersey and UCI Worlds qualification, this is your open-entry pathway. Bring climbing legs for the Driftless.

final_verdict.one_liner: The national championship with open entry‚Äîstars and stripes on Driftless gravel with UCI Worlds pathway.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a legitimate national championship jersey and Worlds qualification. Yes if you appreciate accessible championship racing. Skip if you want destination adventure over competitive credentialing.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Worlds (different title, Nebraska); SBT GRVL (similar region, different vibe); Unbound 200 (bigger field, Kansas gravel)

logistics.airport: LSE (La Crosse Regional) - closest; MSP (Minneapolis-St Paul) - 2.5hr drive; ORD (Chicago) - 4hr drive
logistics.lodging_strategy: La Crosse, WI area has good hotel options. La Crescent is small‚Äîbook early for race weekend. Regional tourism partnerships may offer race-specific deals.
logistics.food: La Crosse has solid dining options. La Crescent is small but race festival adds food options.
logistics.packet_pickup: Pre-race with bike check and registration verification

history.origin_story: USA Cycling established Gravel Nationals in 2023 at Gering, Nebraska, adding gravel to its championship portfolio. The event moved to La Crescent, Minnesota for 2025-26 to showcase Driftless Region terrain. Part of USA Cycling's effort to legitimize gravel racing at the national level.
notable_moments: 2024: Lauren Stephens and Brennan Wertz elite winners
2025: Move to La Crescent/Driftless Region with harder climbing course
history.reputation: Young but legitimate‚Äîthe official path to stars-and-stripes jersey and UCI Gravel Worlds qualification.

course_description.character: Driftless Region 'champagne gravel' with punchy blufftop climbs. The terrain looks Midwestern-gentle but delivers relentless 10-15% gradients throughout. Apple orchards, gravel quarries, and river valley views provide scenery between efforts.

suffering_zones.label: First Driftless Climbs
suffering_zones.desc: The punchy nature reveals itself‚Äîshort, steep pitches that accumulate fatigue early.

suffering_zones.label: Chicken Ridge
suffering_zones.desc: Signature climb with steep gradients. Where the racing shapes up and legs start to feel it.

suffering_zones.label: Accumulated Fatigue
suffering_zones.desc: The repeated climbs compound. What felt punchy early now feels brutal with 100 miles in the legs.

suffering_zones.label: Final Technical Kicker
suffering_zones.desc: 1km climb averaging ~8%. Mountain bike skills matter. Where elite races are decided.

course_description.signature_challenge: The relentless punchy climbs‚Äînot big sustained efforts, but repeated 10-15% gradients that accumulate suffering throughout the championship distance.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: 2024 USA Cycling Gravel National Championships - 131.1 Miles

citations.label: RideWithGPS: 2024 USA Cycling Gravel National Championships - 131.1 Miles
velo.outsideonline.com: What Its Like Competing Pro Gravel Race
thenxrth.com: Gravel Nationals 2025 Preview Everything You Need To Know...

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: USA CYCLING GRAVEL NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS gravel race La Crescent

videos.title: La Crescent welcomes USA Cycling Gravel National Championship for the first time
videos.description: The USA Cycling Gravel National Championships are kicking off in La Crescent, drawing hundreds of cyclists and large crowds to Main Street for registration and the race expo.
videos.transcript:
The USA Cycling Gravel National
Championships roll into Lacrescent this
weekend, bringing hundreds of cyclists
and big crowds to Main Street today for
registration and the race expo. This
year's race features three routes, 31,
74, and 110 miles winding through the
scenic driftlist region of southeastern
Minnesota. 766 riders from across the
country are competing for the Stars and
Stripes jersey in their age group. And
it's not just the racing that's drawing
excitement. Many riders are just as
eager for Lacrescent's Apple Fest.
>> We live in Washington, which is also a
big apple producer and apple market for
the world. And so we're excited to see
the Apple Fest here and visit the Apple
Fest here. And uh uh I've heard the
apple pies are fantastic here. And I I'd
like to try some of that apple pie.
>> The racing starts tomorrow morning at
7:00 a.m. right on Main Street. For more
information on the event, visit
gravelnats.usycling.org.

videos.title: The 2025 USA Cycling Gravel National Championship is Heading to La Crescent, MN
videos.description:
Welcome to La Crescent, Minnesota‚Äôs Apple Capital, and the host of the USA Cycling Gravel National Championships for the next two years! 
The 2025 USA Cycling Gravel National Championships will take place on September 20th, coinciding with La Crescent‚Äôs annual Apple Festival.‚ÄØ¬†Combining our event with their renowned Apple Festival offers another unique experience that we hope our riders and their families can enjoy off the course. We hope to see you there!

For more information about the USA Cycling Gravel National Championships, visit: https://gravelnats.usacycling.org/ 

For more La Crescent/La Crosse local information, visit: https://explorelacrosse.com/usa-cycling-gravel-national-championships-2025/ 

Follow USA Cycling
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/usacycling
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/usacycling/
X: https://twitter.com/usacycling
videos.transcript:
[Music]
Legends aren't born, they're made. At
the 2025 USA Cycling Gravel National
Championship on the rugged back roads of
Minnesota, where every turn tests your
skill in the Crescent, the champagne of
gravel awaits. A course carve through
stunning Bluff Country, where
challenging climbs push your limits and
technical descents test your skill.
Sweeping vistas, rugged ridgeel lines,
and crisp autumn air set the stage for
an unforgettable ride. And when the race
is done, the celebration begins. Because
it's Apple Fest weekend, a town that
lives for the moment, a race unlike any
other. This is your shot at glory. Join
us on September 20th.

videos.title: Preview: 2025 USA Cycling Gravel National Championships p/b Vittoria
videos.description:
The USA Cycling Gravel National Championships presented by Vittoria are September 20 in La Crescent, Minnesota.

Save $25 on your registration with the code TheRide25.

Get more informationa and register at https://gravelnats.usacycling.org/

Want to see what I'm testing and where? Follow me
on Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/ben-delaney
or on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ben_delaney

--
The Ride is supported in 2025 by:
Castelli clothing: https://www.castelli-cycling.com/US/en/
HOVERAir self-flying cameras: https://amzn.to/3ZCzb9V
Perc coffee: https://tinyurl.com/fjr7nurr (save 15% with code 'ride15')
Saris racks: https://saris.com/collections/racks# (save 15% with code 'ben15')
Silca maintenance: https://bit.ly/47xxvzj (save 10% with code 'theridewithbenjune2025')
BikeTiresDirect: https://tinyurl.com/yc7vxujh (save 10% with code 'THERIDE') 
The Cyclist Lawyer: https://www.thecyclist-lawyer.com/
Shimano shoes & glasses: http://tinyurl.com/ye274tep
Feedback Sports stands & tools: https://bit.ly/3S9Dq8r
videos.transcript:
USA Cycling's gravel national
championships is September 20th here in
the drifless region of Minnesota. So,
what are the courses like? The roads,
the surfaces, the hills, the topography.
What is the cycling culture like? We
along with some locals are going to show
you exactly that. Come along for the
ride here in the driftless area of
Minnesota. There are three courses on
tap. The 110 has 7,500 ft of elevation
gain. Most of that in nine distinct
climbs that are roughly a mile long and
500 ft high. The 74 has 5,100 ft of
elevation gain and five main climbs. And
the 31m course has two climbs and just
shy of 2,000 ft total elevation gain.
All three finished on the same circuit
of the stout chicken ridge gravel climb
followed by a run through an apple
orchard and then into the grounds of a
gravel core. All three feature the same
final onem climb that averages 8% before
descending back down into the crescent.
Most of the last five miles is paved
with a gravel kicker up into a
neighborhood followed by a steep and
curved paved descent down into town two
turns before the wide open finish on
Main Street. After 2 years in Garing,
Nebraska, the course here is vastly
different worlds apart. If someone has
not been to this beautiful area, what do
you tell them to expect? What is riding
and racing gravel bikes like here in the
Drifless region?
>> I tell them to expect to have their mind
blown a little bit. Um, you know,
there's nothing, I think, more more
beautiful, more scenic. Expect hills.
Um, expect good gravel, but I think the
the beauty um of the area is fantastic.
>> What about visibility? Like last two
years in Garing, you could see literally
for miles, which is can be a good thing,
can be a demoralizing thing depending on
where you are. Here it seems like
visibility is quite limited. Do you
recommend pre-writing the course or is
the type of thing you could just go out
and enjoy it?
>> No, you definitely need to pre-ride the
course. You need to know the corners.
You need to know where you're going. Um
was talking to Chase work about it this
morning and you know he's like it's
going to be for sure to my advantage to
come out here to know the turns to know
the course. Um the gravel is usually
really good unless they freshly grade
it. But if you know where the tight
turns are in the downhill and how to
line up for that you're going to have a
much better experience for sure. Yeah.
>> I think for the race for sure especially
at the pointy end it's going to be one
of those out of sight out of mind cuz
it's it's almost like a mountain bike
race. It's it's so windy. It's so tight.
It's hilly. It's not like you're going
to see somebody 2 minutes up the road
and you're just going to be watching
that wheel. I think people are going to
going to go and there's enough hills too
um to really break up things and I think
that's really going to be a difference
maker especially in the in the more
elite field.
>> Chase, tell me about the drifless. What
is the drifless area?
>> The the geography answers like the it's
a region in southeastern Minnesota like
southwestern Wisconsin and northeastern
Iowa and like northwest Illinois where
the glaciers didn't drift through and
like flatten the land. And so you have
these bluffs with pretty flat ridges on
top. Um, and then you have like four 500
foot descents into a valley. And usually
there's a lot of streams. There's the
Mississippi River that runs straight
down the middle of the drifless. Um, and
I think it's one of the most beautiful
and underrated parts of the country.
>> What's your advice to people coming out
for gravel nationals?
>> Get ready for some climbing. I don't
think aerodoring out is probably the
best. um thing to do. Get ready for some
really fast roads. Be prepared to
descend. I would make sure you have your
Garmin like zoomed in. If it looks like
a sharp turn on your Garmin or Wahoo,
it's going to be sharp. So, I I want
everyone to be safe. You're not going to
win the race on the downhill, but you
definitely could lose it. So, yeah, stay
within your means. And then yeah, when
you're in the area, stop at a quick
trip, bike along the river. Like I I
hope people can just ride more than just
the gravel. There's a beautiful road
called Apple Blossom just north or out
of north of Lac Crescent. That's a has a
beautiful overview and yeah, that that
would be my advice.
>> Just come enjoy it.
>> Yeah, come and enjoy it.
>> So, how do you live here? You've ridden
here. What are the roads like to ride
and race on? They're absolutely gorgeous
in this area. The views are incredible.
From the rolling bluffs to the beautiful
river views and valleys um behind us,
you'll get some fun farmland, various
different animals and things out on the
road. Our gravel um varies. You will get
some beautiful like pristine um
champagne gravel and then you can all of
a sudden run upon some um nice chunky
stuff.
>> Sure.
>> So,
>> what are the hills like? It seems like
there's there's some steepness to some
of these. Like on coming from Colorado,
it's like, well, no huge mountains, but
there's a lot of elevation gain.
>> The hills around here um are generally
pretty steep, especially on gravel. You
will easily get um 10% plus grades. Um
generally they are less than 500 ft
total elevation gain from bottom to top
just because that's kind of what our um
Mississippi River Valley bluffs are. But
um they can sting a lot. They're that
kind of death by a thousand cuts. You
may not have a two-hour climb, but we
can put a whole bunch of rollers right
next to each other and um your legs will
feel it.
>> As an expert in in both racing and the
bicycle itself, what do you recommend
folks do as far as gearing and tires?
Are you going to need a wide I mean
obviously it's like fitness and personal
preference come into it, but like what
is your recommendation for someone who
is signing up for a national
championships race?
>> The hills are steep. So, if if you um
are from a flatter area, you're going to
want a lot of gearing, whether that's a
double or a single, you know, mullet
setup, big ring in the back, but you're
definitely going to want um a granny
gear. You're going to need to be able to
sit and spin. Sometimes the gravel is
just a little bit loose, too. So, you
really can't stand up when it's 20%. Um
and it's sustained for 5 minutes, and so
it's not like one of those things where
you can kind of punch up it, but like
you're climbing for for an kind of an
extended period. And so, um having the
gearing for that was definitely going to
be helpful. Tire choice, I man, it's
it's wild. Chase and I spent a while
talking about that this morning as well.
I'm currently riding some 55s and I'm
absolutely loving it. But I rode across
the state of Minnesota on gravel last
summer on 35s. Um so you can do it for
sure on a skinnier tire. You're going to
bounce around a lot. You might lose some
time on the descents, but um I expect
the race to be won on a pretty fast,
pretty slim tire.
>> Yeah. Yeah. Like I'm on 42 just straight
up slicks today and Yep.
>> feels fine except for some of those
loosey goosey corners where I'm
definitely taking it on the more
cautious side of things. But Yeah.
>> Yeah. Yeah. Point is like whatever tires
you bring, just
>> enjoy it.
>> I for sure you Yeah. No, I'm I'm running
a a fun gravel ride out here um through
the bike shop. Um and I just told people
you could you could ride a road bike.
You know, if you only have a road bike,
if you have a mountain bike, if you have
a gravel bike, like bring whatever
you've got. Just just know there's not
really a perfect bike or a perfect tire
for for the riding out here.
>> The race starts and finishes in La
Crescent, a small town just across the
mighty Mississippi from Lacrosse,
Wisconsin. And if you like coffee, the
start is just steps away from Avagado
Lane. Coinciding with Nationals, La
Crescent will be hosting its annual
Apple Fest, celebrating the fall harvest
with food, drink, and festivities. Since
the Crescent is small, most riders will
stay in Lacrosse, Wisconsin. A vibrant
three college town home to a great bike
culture and many great shops,
restaurants, and hotels. We started
about 30 years ago, believe it or not,
is a big race in Wisconsin. Shwamagan 40
is a lot on gravel roads. So, we'd come
over here and ride gravel on our
mountain bikes uh to do that. With this
race, it was like looking at all the
routes we had and saying, "Okay, how do
we make it work for a course for
nationals?"
>> Um because there's a million neat roads
here. The question is, how do you
connect the right ones? How do you make
it something where you can have the
support and everybody enjoys it?
>> Um so, I think people will be uh
pleasantly surprised when they get here.
It's not flat.
>> Tell me about road service. What do you
expect the roads to be like come
September?
>> Could be anything. Uh, typically if it's
a good year, you'll have some nice
smooth, fast, flat roads. I mean, they
do a lot of work right now.
>> Um, we got out a month and a half ago,
everything was flat and hard because we
had a nice winter. Now, there's a lot of
loose stuff. They're laying down gravel.
>> Um, they do that all summer long. By the
time nationals get here, it should be in
good shape. But, you know, you could get
a you can get a storm, you have some
nice big ruts in the road. Um we do a
section of minimum maintenance road
later and that's one of those where they
don't do all the maintenance regularly
so it might be interesting that way but
a lot
>> as advertised minimum maintenance road.
>> Yeah. A lot of a lot of good fun roads
but a lot of variety I think
>> if you're going to the race in or out of
Minneapolis. There's all sorts of great
cycling culture here in the Twin Cities
including Angry Catfish
>> around Minneapolis. It's a lot of uh a
lot of city trails. um a really good
crew of people that actually ride out of
this shop, Angry Catfish. We ride around
the lakes, ride around uh to St. Paul,
up to northeast, all around. Um but
we're going to be going down to the
Drifless region. It's just beautiful. Um
it's the area that wasn't affected by
the glaciers making it all flat. So you
get these big bluffs that go up 8-minute
climbs. You're in a valley um in the
farms, see the Amish people on the
horses, and then you go down and you're
around streams and creeks and all the
trout fishing. Um so really cool area to
ride
>> if people are coming in or out of
Minneapolis on their way to or from
there, where is a good spot to get a
nice beverage in Minneapolis?
>> Well, um I would say Bow House Brew
Labs. Um this is uh where I work and
we're a good friend of the shop here at
Angry Catfish. They actually sell some
of our NA beers. We have we got a a big
tap room. Uh lots of bikes bike rack
space there. Um we actually have a bike
team that we sponsor called Hand Up
Racing that does social rides and you
can join on those. They're super fun.
>> A party forward team is how you
described it to me.
>> Yeah, very party forward team.
>> Thanks for making it happen. Thanks,
sir.
>> Yeah. Thanks, man.
>> In addition to all the cool bikes and
merch, inside Angry Catfish, you can
find the workshop of Wild Bikes run by
Jeffrey Fra and his team.
>> Catfish.
Someone asked me to build them a bike
and I was like, "Yeah, no problem. We
can do that." And so I didn't have
anything to do cuz I'd lost my job
because of the pandemic and I ended up
starting a bike brand.
>> How many bikes are you doing in here
with your team?
>> We do production bikes in Taiwan.
>> Yep.
>> And that's really, you know, the main
focus of the business. And then we have
our workshop here. And Brad is our
full-time frame builder. And we'll build
between 40 and 50 frames here in house.
We don't do any welding, so everything
is either lugged or fillet braced.
>> Paul's been driving support for us all
day. Thanks, sir. Appreciate that.
>> Absolutely.
>> Where are we now, sir? And what are we
about to do? What will Racers be doing
here?
>> Uh, well, we will be climbing up uh one
of the bluffs.
>> The racers will actually be racing
through the lanes of apple trees in the
in the orchards uh followed up by a
gravel corey. We thought it'd be a great
little uh combination to a show off from
the some spots on the top of the bluff.
You can actually see the Mississippi
River which is not too far away and uh
it'll be some pretty sights for the for
the racers and for uh for spectators
alike. So,
>> and with the race being September 20th
in the fall, that's Prime Apple season,
isn't this? Like Apple Fest is going on
the weekend of the race going on as
well. You can see the apples. Probably
not stopping to sample here, but just
getting to see where the where the goods
are coming from.
>> Yes,
>> we're at the top of the gravel quarry.
There's just not a better way to end uh
the gravel national championships than
going through the apple orchard in
conjunction with Apple Fest and then the
gravel corey.
>> We're going through the sources of both
things.
>> Tell us about Apple Fest.
>> Yeah, so Apple Fest is long-standing
festival uh celebration of the apple
capital of Minnesota, which is Lac
Crescent. And uh um you know just a
great get together celebrating all
things apple. Apple pies you know the
crumbles, the crisps, the you name it,
the cers. Um certainly some beers will
probably be drank during that time.
>> Need some insider info. What's what's
the best apple dessert I should be
requesting after gravel nationals?
>> I mean personally I'm a crisp guy. Okay,
>> so that's that's where I'm going to go
every time.
>> Okay. Straight to the apple crisp.
>> Yeah, absolutely. For sure.
>> Thanks, Jeremia.
>> Absolutely. Thank you. The 2025 USA
Cycling Gravel National Championships
presented by Victoria and locally
championed by Explore Minnesota is
September 20th in Lac Crescent,
Minnesota. Check the links in the video
description below for full information
and to register.
videos.curation_reason: Detailed course preview from respected cycling channel with specific terrain analysis and local insights.

videos.title: USA Gravel Nationals 2025 | RAW HIGHLIGHTS
videos.description:
Here we are in La Crescent, MN, just 2 hours away from my home town of Mankato, MN, for the 2025 USA Cycling gravel Nationals. With this being so close to home and on terrain with short to medium punchy climbs that suits my riding style so well, It's safe to say this was the race I was most excited for all season.

SPOILER ALERT HERE: Everything was going perfect to plan, right on Pete and Alexey up the first 4 climbs, and even off the front for a small bit after climb number 4. Then, disaster. I dropped a bottle in Aid 2 and thought I could stop to grab it, but the bottle had exploded. The 7 seconds of stopping time I had here to get another one was Amplified by the fact that it was on a DH and the defending champ was attacking through it, and by the time I got going again it was too late.

So much "would have, could have, should have" with this one, but I will take from this knowlege to learn and grow, as we can often find more growth in our failures than in our successes.

videos.curation_reason: High-quality first-person race recap with excellent production value and substantial viewership from actual 2025 event.

videos.title: First 20 Miles of the 2025 USA Gravel National Championship
videos.curation_reason: First-person ride-along showing actual race conditions and course terrain from the 2025 event.

quotes.text: The 110 has 7,500 ft of elevation gain. Most of that in nine distinct climbs that are roughly a mile long and 500 ft high. All three courses finish on the same circuit of the stout chicken ridge gravel climb followed by a run through an apple orchard and then into the grounds of a gravel core.
You definitely need to pre-ride the course. You need to know the corners. You need to know where you're going. It's almost like a mountain bike race. It's so windy. It's so tight. It's hilly.

This year's race features three routes, 31, 74, and 110 miles winding through the scenic driftless region of southeastern Minnesota. 766 riders from across the country are competing for the Stars and Stripes jersey in their age group.

key_challenges.name: Chicken Ridge gravel climb
key_challenges.description: All three courses finish on the same circuit featuring the stout chicken ridge gravel climb followed by a run through an apple orchard.

key_challenges.name: Final mile climb
key_challenges.description: All three courses feature the same final one mile climb that averages 8% before descending back down into La Crescent.

key_challenges.name: Nine distinct climbs
key_challenges.description: The 110 mile course has nine distinct climbs that are roughly a mile long and 500 ft high.

key_challenges.name: Technical descents and tight turns
key_challenges.description: Riders emphasize you need to know the corners and where the tight turns are in the downhills to line up properly.

terrain_notes.text: The gravel is usually really good unless they freshly grade it.
The course features bluffs with pretty flat ridges on top, then 400-500 foot descents into valleys with streams.
Most of the last five miles is paved with a gravel kicker up into a neighborhood followed by a steep and curved paved descent down into town.

gear_mentions.text: Make sure you have your Garmin like zoomed in. If it looks like a sharp turn on your Garmin or Wahoo, it's going to be sharp.
I don't think aeroing out is probably the best thing to do for this course.

race_day_tips.text: You definitely need to pre-ride the course. You need to know the corners. You need to know where you're going.
Get ready for some climbing. Get ready for some really fast roads. Be prepared to descend.
It's going to be out of sight out of mind because it's almost like a mountain bike race. It's so windy. It's so tight. It's hilly.

additional_quotes.text: The racing starts tomorrow morning at 7:00 a.m. right on Main Street.
766 riders from across the country are competing for the Stars and Stripes jersey in their age group.
It's not just the racing that's drawing excitement. Many riders are just as eager for Lacrescent's Apple Fest.

rider_intel.search_text: USA Cycling Gravel Nationals moved from Nebraska to La Crescent, Minnesota in the driftless region. The 110-mile course features 7,500 feet of elevation gain with nine distinct climbs roughly one mile long and 500 feet high. All courses finish on the chicken ridge gravel climb through an apple orchard, ending with a final one-mile climb averaging 8 percent grade. The terrain features bluffs with flat ridges and 400-500 foot descents into valleys. Riders emphasize pre-riding is essential due to limited visibility, tight turns, and technical descents. The gravel surface is typically good unless freshly graded. The course is described as windy, tight, and hilly like a mountain bike race. Racing starts at 7 AM on Main Street during Apple Fest weekend, drawing 766 riders competing for national championship jerseys across three distance options.
